Même pas un geste commercial, avec le café gratuit...

Beeeees everywhere! They don't bother you too much but they will eat your food and drink your drink. You just have to take turns. 

Food tasty and location sociable and enjoyable ... just expect to be in the background of many pictures if you're seated outside since people like to pose at the entrance to this strip. Perfect photobombing opportunities.

As of 9/2/12 ... they were hiring.

Loved this quaint little spot right in the midst of the Old Port. We sat inside right next to a wide open window; it was lovely. I ordered La Parisienne crèpe, DELICIOUS! All the other meals ordered within my party were also deemed fantastic. We also ordered a desert crèpe, so so good. If you're visiting in summer, I recommend the frozen cappuccino. Overall, food was 10/10 with good prices, good environment as well. Our server was so friendly and efficient as well! Definitely try this place.

This place is much much larger than it seems.  Highly recommend making a reservation in advance!  The crepes were delicious!  I had Brie in mine and it was melted perfectly.  The portion size was large.  The crepe was also the perfect thickness and cooked just right.  It wasn't soggy and it wasn't burnt to a crisp.

Highly recommend if you're in old Montreal!

I gave it three stars for the selection, the somewhat helpful wait staff and the great location.  Maybe my expectations were too high. The two crepes lacked flavour, breakfast and spinach & Brie. The breakfast crepe  was really tough. Cutting it was almost a disaster. 
I really enjoyed the escargot, the onion soup and the overpriced strawberry drink.  The onion soup tasted great but I was expecting it to be fancier, such as a homemade cracker baked on top.
Such excellent service and food at lunch that we came back for dinner since we were just too tired to make any other decisions.  We didn't regret the choice at all.  Don't miss the Crepe Suzette!

I visited this place a few years ago when I had the craving for fondue. Returned and was happy to find that the place still existed. Yes, it's a total tourist trap - but one that doesn't gouge folks then delivers poor food. The cheese fondue selection was sparse but pretty solid and combined with a half liter of wine, meant a splendid albeit lingering lunch. Highly recommend eating on the third floor which had a nicer atmosphere to it. The cheese fondue filled us up, so sadly we didn't have enough space for the meat fondue, which I remembered from last time, was divine and had the superb bonus of drinking the 'soup' after you had finished cooking all your meat in it.

The dessert crepe here with bananas and almonds is one of the top three desserts I've had in my life.  My husband and I stumbled across it in 2010 and purposely sought it out on this trip, now with our 2-year-old.  It lived up to the memory we had of it, and even our toddler loved it.  We didn't try the meal crepes, but we can't say enough about the dessert crepes here.  We will go out of our way to eat here every time we come to Montreal.

Soup l'ognion de gratinée is a must! 
French onion soup was spot on!

Hubby enjoyed his Le campagnarde crêpe!

We got the strawberries and nutella crepe.  The crepe was nice and chewy with a thin layer of nutella (not overwhelming to make the crepe too sweet or soggy) with a scoop of ice cream in the middle and sweet strawberries.  A very good crepe overall!
Not great... Not bad.  Probably around average for the Old Port.   Fondue is just decent, wine prices are really good, crepes are ok.

Chez Suzette is conveniently located in the heart of Vieux Montreal. Its outdoor seating as well as the second floor tables offer scenic views of tourists walking along Rue Saint Paul. When I visited, the wifi was broken, which was a bummer as wifi is super useful for a tourist visiting another country. 

The crepe itself was good but nothing particularly special. It was surprisingly filling and left my stomach with little space for dessert. The fondue options looked quite good based on what I saw from the tables around me, but if you're in the mood for simple crepe with a nice view then this is your dinner place

Beware: the coke is not offical post mix but a rip off no name brand cola.
The quiche is microwaved to the same temperature of the sun and only given a spoon to eat it with.
Complimentary bread came out after the mains not warmed with butter and still no other utensil but a spoon.
French onion soup was quite bland but the cheese on top was nice, maybe a 2/5.
Lobster bisque has more cognac than any other flavour, a 1/5.
Vegetable quiche 1/5, frozen, microwaved then smashed in the oven.
The McDonald's around the corner would provide more satisfaction.

Old Montreal...you are a delight to the visual sense.

-Delice Special: Scrambled eggs, bacon, ham, swiss cheese, mushrooms, and MAPLE SYRUP!!

As you can tell, I am ecstatic about the maple syrup. Whats even better is that the bacon is ham-like, lean, and very filling. 

Only regret it that I didn't get a chance to try a dessert crepe. Shame on me!

When you're on vacation anything goes. An by anything I mean consuming a giant-sized dish of crepes, smothered in vanilla ice cream drizzled with Belgian chocolate, and piled high with strawberries and bananas--FOR BREAKFAST!

On a snowy Montreal morning, we sat on the street level of this charming little creperie, watching the passersby and wondering how on earth they survived this weather without proper bundling! I kid you not, some of these people were in track jackets or heavy sweatshirts! I was but only thankful to be inside this warm, delicious smelling restaurant!

With three floors and several pages of crepes to choose from (plus quiche and other fun foods) you'll find a place to plant your bum and some yum to fill your tum in no time!

Cant miss. Nestled in the old Montreal district, this is a great stop out of the cold. Warm up with the Crepe Suzette, the best crepe on the menu.
Highly recommended

Cute little restaurant and sidewalk café on one of the most beautiful streets anywhere. I had the roast beef sandwich on focaccia bread and it was delicious. Nice sized too. On the day that we were there, it took forever to get waited on, but to be fair, it was the lunchtime rush. Once we finally did get waited on, everything went without a hitch.

I'd like to go back and try breakfast here some time. With sidewalk dining in fair weather, this is a perfect place to relax and enjoy the sights. Fun for people watching too.

Chez Suzette was a highlight of our trip to Montreal; the vibe was cozy, the staff friendly, and the food was hearty French deliciousness. Their French onion soup was heavenly -- such a flavorful broth without feeling too heavy (a tough balance to strike!). And highly recommend the sundried tomato fondue as well. We split amongst four people and it was the perfect way to kick off the meal. Can't recommend this place enough!

The staff was very friendly, and the ambiance was cute, but unfortunately, the food was a miss. I ordered the La Speciale Delice crepe but it was very bland and not worth $14.99. On the other hand, the Viennese coffee was pretty good.
Visited for breakfast on a quiet Sunday morning. The crêpes were ok, a bit chewy. Not sure I'd return.

Not impressed -- my husband came for desert -- ordered a crepe 
Besides the fact that the crepe was old and required force to tear it apart the waiter didn't ask us how anything was and we had to sit for 15 min after finishing up get our bill and pay for this terrible meal

The smoothies were amazing!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  My crepe of chicken and mushrooms was very good. The waiter, Pedro, was very kind and attentive! The service was very fast! You may think that crepes only work with sweet things, not true. The breakfast crepe, my brother says, is really good. I tried the maple syrup.  The music was superb! This is possibly one of the best places I've every eaten at, and definitely the best in Montreal! The dessert looked just as good as it tasted. It was amazing!!! I came here another day and there was a waiter named Martin. We asked him for directions to some places and he gave us everything we anted plus more! This place was so good that the four days I was in Montreal, I came here 2 times!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
We stopped in here for lunch today and what a wonderful decision! We loved our meals and desserts. The crepes are incredible, especially the dessert crepes. Highly recommended.

We stopped in here for a late afternoon lunch on a rainy Sunday and it was still really busy. It isn't really anything special, but the cocktails were really delicious. The food was pretty good but not great. No complaints about the service. The atmosphere needs some updating and a cleanup, and they really need to change the music playlist!

My first meal in Montreal and it was a delicious one. I was walking around the Old Montreal craving a crepe and a bailey's hot chocolate. This cute little creperie appeared magically at the corner of the street and I knew it was a sign to go in and try it. We sat next to the window and it was really lovely. We split and ham and cheese crepe and a swiss fondue, while sipping delish boozed hot chocolates. Such a gre8 way to start a trip!

What's better for breakfast on your last day in Montreal than crepes?  Glad you agree.  Just down the street from our hotel was Creperie Suzzette with a sidewalk café.  Perfect!

Two cups of coffee ($4.98), La Speciale Delice ($14.99) stuffed with scrambled eggs, ham, bacon, Swiss cheese, and mushrooms, and La Parisienne ($13.99) stuffed with Brie cheese and fresh apples.  What a nice sendoff this turned out to be.

Portions were very generous and each of our crepes came with real maple syrup.  Service was very good considering they got slammed as soon as they opened.  Fortunately for us, we arrived just as the kitchen was catching up with the initial rush.  The crepes may have been a bit tough, but the flavor and fillings made up for that.
We sat in the third floor. The Crepes and coffee were amazing.  I had la sonia the strawberries and bananas were just right.

Looks very good.  Big menu, lots of seating!  Hot upstairs though!  We ordered dessert crepes.  Found a way to open the window by our table and drank in the cool night breezes.  The crepes were huge, and wonderful just the right amount of sweetness.

Stopped by just in passing after lunch elsewhere for a dessert crepe. We were impressed by a varied menu that included not only a large selection of dessert crepes but also many meat and cheese crepes, varied fondues, and other items. We decided on a crepe with strawberries, bananas, dark chocolate sauce, and vanilla ice cream.....yum! The service was very good and the crepe was delivered quickly. It was a good find!
Not the best crepes we had in Montreal but you can't beat the location or the view. When the weather is nice it's a great place to sit and people watch.

Stumbled upon while walking Old Town. Yummy crepes and soups. Returned for dinner since we enjoyed the experience so much & not disappointed. Love the colorful interior. Upstair window table is enjoyable

Although a few dollars more than I would have liked to pay, my crepe with Brie, ham, and caramelized onions was quite good. It came with syrup so at the end I dipped the crepe bits in the extra syrup to get that nice salty sweet. Pretty cute, great location. We needed to get in and out quickly to catch a flight and they were very nice about it.
Man, I hated the ambiance. The outdoor seating looked nice, but indoors it's tacky and plain. Service and the food were both average. Would absolutely not recommend this place.

My wife and I shared sangria, savory crepe with chicken, spinach and Brie (slight up charge to substitute chicken for ham) and finished with chocolate fondue.   Great food, nice casual atmosphere and it was a bonus that our waiter, Jolain, on the third floor was terrific.

Convenient location. Friendly staff. Extensive selection. We had three spongey crepes: ham with asparagus and bechamel sauce; egg, bacon, mushroom and cheese; and a dessert crepe with bananas and Nutella. The crepes were not light and airy but rather spongey. The fillings were average-- processed ham, etc. A disappointment overall.
Very good atmosphere.  The staff was very friendly.  Service was amazingly fast.  The took kids with no problem.  I would recommend for any tourist if you'd like a quick and easy taste.

Came here for a bite while strolling in Old Montreal. Ordered the French onion soup baked with crouton topped with cheese, and also got a ham, brie and spinach crepe topped with bechamel sauce. 

Didn't really like the soup, thought that there was way too much cheese, about a lb of it sitting on top of the soup which was kind of gross and the base wasn't very flavourful. Crepe itself was very delicious and smelled amazing. The fillings and the sauce worked together but it wasn't my favorite combination. 

The place itself was pretty big, 3 levels, friendly staff, decent prices. Decent choice for food if you are in the area.
We enjoyed a stop at Suzette for crepes and fondue.  We enjoyed the salad and French onion soup as well as the savory crepes and ended our meal with fondue.  Friendly and fast service.

I visited the Creperie on a trip home from Canada. We decided that while passing through Montreal we would stop and get something to eat there. After browsing a few review It was decided that the Creperie sounded the most appealing. 
We sat downstairs and ordered some drinking and soup and a crepe each. The hot cider I ordered was really good. I opted for the Non-alcoholic version since, this was about the time for brunch; even though I'm sure it was 5 o'clock somewhere. Then the soup came out which was out of this world. It cost about 9 dollars but was completely worth it. Finally I had my bacon and avocado crepe, which was all I had hoped it would be, although not being too surprised as how could you really go wrong with both bacon and avocado in something.  
The girl who waited on us was very pleasant the whole time. Overall I was very pleased with the choice of lunch.

My crawl through Old Montreal eateries continued in here when the family decided crepes and fondue were the ticket for dinner.  Located on the corner on Rue St. Paul, it's in a prime spot.  

The menu consists mostly of a variety of sweet and savory crepes, sandwiches, quiches, salads and fondues.  The cheese fondue was good and they gave plenty of bread to dip.  My only critique would be that they were a bit heavy with the white wine but that's a personal preference.  The smoked salmon salad was good with a nice amount of smoked salmon.  The crepes were also good but they were a bit heavy on the béchamel and cheese for my liking.  

All in all a good bite but kind of expensive (which is to be expected here).  Solid 3.5 stars.

friend and i went visiting from states.  it was frigid and we decided on crepes.  i almost ordered the quiche because it looked better.  wish i did.  it was meaty and thats about it.

friend had bitter cream sauce on hers

maybe we just ordered crap and the other stuff was better, but i cant rate on 'ifs and buts'

Stopped in while visiting old Montreal.. it was perfect. I had a crepe with bananas, almonds, toffee cream, and ice cream. Delicious is an understatement. Warmed up with a half pitcher of sangria. Truly enjoyed this place and I will be back when I visit Montreal again.

This place looks like a small crêperie from the outside, but it's giant in the inside - 3 floors of dining rooms? 

It's more professional than I was expecting too, so obviously I got different results. Not that the crêpe is even close to bad, but you know, they just make the pastry, add some pre-cut fruits and cover it in chocolate sauce. This by any means can taste bad. But when the fruit is fresh cut it tastes better, when they make the crêpe with the fruit, everything tastes different (the fruits are a bit warm), etc. 

So, it's just a 3-star crêpe. I have had better ones. Service was standard, everything was three-star.

Hard to find French restaurant which is vegetarian friendly. But we did it somehow and it turned out to be really good. Location is the prime factor. Beautiful place to eat at. Be prepared to wait longer to be seated during summer weekends...

Best crepes ever!!! After traveling through Quebec and Montreal and tasting crepes everywhere I am most definitely recommend Creperie Chez Suzette is the place to go try them, whether you've never had one before or had tons of them. We liked it so much we came two days in a row. The restaurant is located right by the busiest part of old Montreal.There is an outdoor and indoor seating, it was kind of fun seat outside and watch people go by. The crepe menu is full of choices, both for meat lovers and vegetarians. The first time there I had crepe Romanoff (strawberries, whipped cream and ice cream) and my friend had crepes with bananas, whipped cream, ice cream, topped with chocolate sauce. The second time I had a dinner crepe with chicken and mushroom sauce, which was not as delicious as dessert one, but still extermely good. Your visit to Montreal will not be complete without going to Chez Suzette.

I was a bit dissapointed with my first real crepe experience. The place has plenty of room with three floors but is still a very cramped environment .We walked in and sat and the waiters walked past us for about ten minutes before someone came over. For drinks, we got a bloody caesar and the cocoloco smoothie. They mistakenly made a bloody mary and informed us, which I was fine with. The drink though, was virtually all tomato juice and I couldn't taste any tabasco/pepper or vodka, and there was no celery or garnish. Probably the worst bloody mary I have ever had. The cocoloco was pretty good, but very artificial tasting. I got the crepe charlevoix, which was generous portion. Even though I was hungry, it wasn't that good. I do wish they had more meat options with their crepes. The dessert crepes looked very good but I wasn't in the mood for one. I tried the quiche which was decent. Overall, not worth the $50+ bill for a crepe, quiche, and two drinks.

Walking around the old town, we came across this restaurant. Although they were very busy we were able to get a table right away. They had a upstairs seating that was very nice. Our waiter was very nice and gladly agreed to replace bananas for marshmallows on my dish. But he failed to tell me there will be a charge for replacement. He claimed the cook had added the $2 banana fee. Now I know from eating out for over 40 years, when you ask for a replacement that's just what it is,a replacement. But he did want to offer me the $2 out of his own pocket which I thought was a nice gesture.

This place was great! This was just what you needed to get out of the cold Montreal air.  The French onion soup was absolutely delicious. We ordered the sun dried tomato cheese fondue and the waiter gave us extra bread. Loved the atmosphere, server and food - very cozy place and exceptional service. Great price too! I highly recommend :D

We are not in the habit of complaining BUT this is quite simply a truly terrible crepe place. The reason is very simple: they pre-cook all their crepes in the morning and then they microwave them before serving, the result is a disaster. The crepe is not fresh of course, the texture is terrible, hot in some spots and cold in others. Becuase it is cooked hours before and microwaved the ingredients inside the crepe fight with each other.  We give them 5 stars for honesty: when asked they admitted that they pre-cook their crepes. We know crepes and this is absolutely NOT how a crepe is supposed to be enjoyed. 

Definitely a tourist trap because of its lovely location in the heart of Old Montreal.

[Montreal Food Tour Stop #6] Big crepes, savory and sweet, along with other breakfast food in a hopping part of Old Montreal.  There's an upstairs and downstairs dining room in this restaurant.  On a nice day, the windows will be open for fresh air.

Highlights: Large, tasty crepes.  I ordered Crepe La Sonia, which is a large dessert crepe that includes strawberries, bananas, and hot chocolate sauce.  As a bonus, there's vanilla ice cream served on the side.  The crepe looked great and was sprinkled with powdered sugar.  There was a lot of fruit on the inside and the crepe itself was fluffy.  Yummy and sweet, but not too sweet.

Critiques: The bananas in the crepe were a little overripe.  The crepe was big and very good, but it was a little expensive ($13-14 CAD) for a crepe of this quality.  I was probably paying a little more for the atmosphere.

Overall: Solid crepes in a popular touristy part of town.  The flavor was very good overall.

Decent ambience, cute in a way, on St. Paul, college/younger crowd, OK service, rather expensive for crepes...Crepes were good but not authentic French...They were the white flour kind, and not the "saracen" f darker flour crepes you should have when you eat your "salty" meal crepes...So I guess I'm still on the lookout for the perfect crepe place in Montreal...

Not impressed. Waiter seemed to be in a bad mood and my party of 3 felt rushed to place our order. Soup and crepe were good but I couldn't rate my crepe due to the fact that it never came. I love old Montréal but I have to tell you that there are better places for one to spend their tourist dollar.

Ah Old Montreal.. the European charm, the cobble stone street, the tourist traps... Yeah, this place has decent food for higher than average prices, but it makes up for it with comfortable outdoor seating, or multiple levels inside with nice cool AC for those muggy Montreal summers. 

Ordered a bottle of San Pellegrino with lemon for the glasses and we enjoyed a lunch of savory crepes - specifically the spinach, ham and brie filled one and a brie with caramelized onion sandwich. The sandwich came with a nice little side salad. Everything was tasty. Service was friendly, but leisurely which is fine when you are vacation. 

I wouldn't recommend this place as a destination, but if you are in the area looking to people watch with your meal this place fits the bill nicely directly on Rue Saint-Paul Est.

We stumbled upon this little gem almost by chance, and we were so glad we did.

It's a cute little creperie (with all kinds of other food too) located in the Old Port. Very friendly waitresses, and a beautiful intimate feel. Also it didn't have the pomp or prices of the old port, just comfortable and intimate.

We ordered a variety of crepes, salads, and soup, and we loved everything. Really great spot and we'll likely come anytime we're in the old port. So happy to find it.

Had the Mediterranean crepe with chicken and ratatouille and it was absolutely delicious! The ground floor was super cozy right along Saint Paul. Le Remy was a delicious drink and so was the Cidre Chaud, however the Cidre Chaud seemed a little overpriced given how tiny the cup was. Nonetheless delicious food and drinks in Old Port!

J étais un habitué. Quand on vient souper un trio de fondu 75$ pour deux, puis un mouton cadet à 23$, on a s'attend à autre chose que de la viande de buf servie noire, une fois puis deux fois après avoir demandé un changement d'assiette. De plus la viande avait un goût de poisson, pour la deuxième assiette. La troisième avait l air correcte, mais bon deux expérience négative ça coupe l'appétit. En plus, limite on te rit à la face .. 
C'est bon ça suffit. 
Tu prends un café pour terminer le souper, et la facture. 138 $ taxes et tip compris,Tu paies plein pot. Tu crois qu'ils auraient offert le café pour s'excuser ? Même pas ! Bonjour le sens du commerce ...

I must admit, I didn't get the crepes here. Instead, I got a fulfilling meal of fondue, both swiss and chinoise. That was plentiful for 2 people, I can't imagine how full my tummy would be if I also got the chocolate fondue.

The cheese fondue was excellent -- creamy and savory, served with the usual bread cubes and fruits. The broth fondue was good too! It looked very plain when it was served -- with a plate of meats and a plate of typical vegetables (mushrooms, broccoli, etc), but the actual beef broth was mouthlickingly delicious! So unassuming, yet so yummy.

They also have a few affordable wines, which go well with the delicious meal. Service is a bit sparse (well, not quite saccharin like south of the border anyway), but it's sufficient, and in line with other places around here, if only a little bit slow.

This place was pretty good. The outside is deceiving though because it looks small up close but it is massive on the inside! So don't expect to get a quick lunch here on the weekend. The cheese fondue was nice. We got the herbs, spices, and dried tomato fondue which was ok. We enjoyed it more with the fruit and not so much with the bread. The bread had dried olives in it or something that gave it a bitter taste. We also ordered a BLT which was fresh, hot, and tasty. I just wish the wait hadn't been so long because we had a lot of sightseeing we wanted to do.

Do not come here for fondue. It's advertised as a fondue restaurant but it was not good.

Waitress was friendly but so slow considering half the resto was empty when we arrived.

They didn't even use fondue pots. They used a camping stove and an old pot.

The skewers were all melted.

The sauces were more like salad dressing than fondue sauce.

The chicken was hardly cut so the peices were too large to cook quickly and even then we werent sure if it was cooked well.

And more importantly it was $50 a person. The best fondue spots in Montreal don't charge this much.

The crepe with brie, apples, and maple syrup changed my life.

I'm not kidding.

In a street full of tourist-trap restaurants, this one stands out simply because they make some solid crepes and soups.

I was expecting the crepes to be decent and this place didn't disappoint.  The vegetable crepe was really well made and the portions were pretty sizeable.  

I also tried the montreal salmon bagel and it was a pretty good sandwich.  Very simple but the salmon was really tasty.  

What surprised me about this place was how good their French Onion soup was.  The cheese was perfectly baked and the soup was just right.  Not too salty and not too onion-ny.  I was very pleased with the meal as a whole.

The place gets pretty packed during peak hours and you may expect to wait a while, but they have a lot of seating upstairs as well.

The french onion soup and crepes but best of all the hot chocolate!  Chocolat au chaud!!  This restaurant is like a little cozy, several stories of goodness.  A lot of tourists but SO WHAT!  The waiter was cordial and told us what tourists usually order so we actually went against all of that.. since we wanted to be different! HAHAHA

Anyways, aside from the soup, we ordered the escargot.  Also ordered a few crepes to try.  It was all very good.  

I am so glad to have checked out this place!

We just wanted a quick snack. Had the Nutella with Banana Crepe and the Cinnamon Apple Crepe. It was okay. Nothing spectacular. 

Waiter kept refilling the coffee without us having to ask. Very attentive. Checked on us regularly without being intrusive. 

We came in the afternoon and had a corner table on the first floor. Nice spot for people watching.

My children (12 and 14 year old boy and girl), really enjoyed ourselves and our meal.  We all ordered lunch crepes and they were delicious.  Afterwards the kids ordered chocolate fondue.  The service was great!  The food was excellent.
Small portion sizes, barely filling and average taste overall.

The crepes were just ok, actually the tea glace (iced) was the best we had but my asparagus crepe was too sweet for a savory filling and rubbery. We were hot and had 2 glasses of the iced tea so that made us happy.

It takes forever to get served.  It is a chain -- so the dishes aren't awesome.  Seems the sweet crepes are better (or at least look better) than the savory ones, we did not stick around to find out.  The savory crepes though... First of all, they don't taste so good.  The crepes are soggy, the chicken is a bit dry and the cream sauce put us in the bathroom for 2 days.  So, I would say never again

My husband and I stopped by Crêperie Chez Suzette on our way back from a nice day at Montreal's Old Port this spring. Since he is Texan, I thought it would be a good occasion to have him try another sample of Québécois cuisine. Unfortunately, however, the food turned out to be quite bland; although it didn't taste bad, it lacked the je ne sais quoi which makes a meal memorable. I had the Crêpe Argenteuil and he had Quiche Provençale, both of which seriously lacked seasoning. Other than that, their coffee and drinks were fair and their staff was pleasant enough.

Conclusion: Since my cooking's better and tastier, next time I'll Isave my money to buy fresh ingredients and cook those dishes at home.
Fondue was good, I would totally skip the savory crepes. They were nothing to write much about

Absolutely divine crepes, very indulgent and yet not so filling that you feel stuffed afterwards.

We were warmly greeted at the door by the hostess and immediately seated (a nice surprise at noon on a holiday Monday in the touristy part of town!) at a table in the middle of the room, then she promptly moved us to a table near the window as soon as she finished cleaning and resetting it, without us even asking.

The service was quick and polite, coffee was refilled without us needing to ask and the crepes... well, they were delicious.

I ordered Le Sonia, which was strawberries, bananas, vanilla ice cream and chocolate sauce. My husband had Le Jamaicaine, which was similar, but without strawberries. Both of us easily finished our crepes and one of the two scoops of ice cream, were satisfied and agreed that there was no way we could have had a savory crepe and then the sweet ones, so I think it's the type of place we'd return for a dessert or specifically for savory ones for a meal. The coffee was even very good (Cafe Brossard brand, I believe) and provided a nice balance to the dessert crepes.

Came here with the mind set of splitting a crepe. Nope. Each got a dessert crepe. No regrets. Crepe is a bit chewy but overall the quality was so good, fruit is fresh, ice cream is good. A little on the pricey side but that's what you would expect for the crepe. They have a nice patio outside and service is quick. Going into a sugar coma now.

We came for breakfast and sat on the beautiful patio and had wonderful service. All 5 of us loved our crêpes!! The Parisienne especially, with brie and green apples, yummmm. I would highly recommend, great food, service and ambiance for the price.

Another favorite of mine whenever I come and visit Montreal. I've been coming here since 2011 and a must get when coming here is their Toffee Crepe with Ice Cream plus their Escargot and French Onion Soup. If your ever in Old Montreal, drop on by. You won't regret it.

Located in the old port of Montreal, this three-stories restaurant has a warm and cozy feeling and a great selection of crepes, with meats or as desserts! I tried shrimp crepe, which was something very new to me and I absolutely loved it!

I understand that lots of places like to seat people next to the window because it makes the restaurant look full. But when your windows don't have curtains and the sun is shining in right on the table, you probably shouldn't do that. That's what happened to us, and we probably should've moved, but I thought the sun would feel good. It did for the first 5 minutes, but I was sweating by the end. Why don't they have curtains? Strange.

Our food was decent, I had the club sandwich and upgraded to a Caesar salad for $1.50. The salad was great, the sandwich was OK, but the bacon wasn't crispy and I think the chicken was the canned type. The bread was toasted so much that it actually hurt my mouth when I bit into it. On the upside, the service was very good.

Stopped in for a quick bite to eat before doing more sight seeing in Old Montreal.

The menu is long with a large variety of salty and sweet choices.

We decided on crêpes!

1.  Parisienne: apple, brie cheese, with Quebec maple syrup 

2. Class Sucre Creme:  toffee cream

The Parisienne crêpe was tasty but the toffee cream was much more delicious!

Decor is trying for a quaint Parisian look and feel but falls a bit short with dated fixtures and furniture.  

The view from the second and third floor is nice with large talk windows and the atmosphere with the nice summer breeze and the church bells makes for a pleasant dining experience.

Wait staff is average and speak both French and English, which helps.

A delicious choice for this beautiful strech of shops and restaurants down in Old Montreal.  We ate here at about 11am and sat upstairs where we could look down on the cobblestone streets below.  I had the crepes with smoked salmon, capers, red onion, lemon, cucumber and cream cheese.  They forgot the cream cheese but gave me some on the side which was okay with me.  I constructed each bite the same and the cream cheese was helping the bits of red onion, capers and tomato stay on my perfect little bites.  My wife made fun of me for this.

My wife had apples, brie and maple syrup inside her crepes and let me tell you, that was outstanding... unbelievable flavor and it had sweet, savory and creamy in every bite.  This was real maple syrup as well which definitely has a distict flavor which wouldn't have worked as well if it were corn starch american pancake syrup.

Our only regret was that it was morning still or my wife would have had one of their specialty drinks which was a blackberry icecream shake, booze, cherry juice and fudge.  Yeah, sounds too good to be true.

Crepes are mediocre at best. Barely any nutella. Feels like they opened up a store bought crepe, spread as thin of a nutella layer as they could and microwaved it. If you're ok with mediocre crepes than go for it. But i suggest paying a few more dollars and going to Cacao 70 10mins away for a real crepe.

Stopped here for lunch, after taking a walking tour, and very glad we did. The food was very pleasant, we had the lunch special, which included soup, crepes, tea, and a dessert for the incredible bargain price of $9.99 CAD. All of the food was well-prepared, tasty, and served by a very friendly waiter, in timely fashion, and all in a lovely, welcoming, atmosphere, in a quirky old building in Old Montreal. If you find yourself in the Old Port, and want a pleasant meal, this place is worth a try.

As first-timers in Old Montreal and ones with young kids, we were thankful to have come upon this place.  After an exciting day at the Montreal Science  Center (which is very, very close from here), we were all starving!  We thought that this place was perfect for us that night because the ambience was charming, if not romantic, and yet, very accommodating to little ones.  

We were fortunate to have a server who was very sensitive to our family's needs.  She suggested that we share the crepes with our daughters (as opposed to ordering separate for us) because they were big enough servings. So, that worked out well.  In fact, in the end, we were all too full for desserts.  We had the La Quebecoise (with Swiss cheese, ham and Quebec maple syrup) and the Chicken Supreme (chicken pieces and ala King sauce).  And boy, I would never forget my husband's and 1 yr old's first taste of escargot!  We also had a fine bottle of Brouilly, which our server suggested.

Food was actually simple and really unimpressive.  But, like I said, it was perfect for us that evening!

And just to add a note to parents: There was no changing table inside the toilettes but you might want to try out what one mom did: she used the top of the deep freezers laying by the coat racks as her baby station.  I think it works well!

My fiancé and I wandered into this restaurant while exploring the Old City, and luck was on our side! Beautiful place with tables overlooking Rue Saint Paul (would suggest getting a window table if possible).  I got the brie and leek quiche, which was recommended to me by our server, and it was fantastic.

Overall an excellent experience, and I don't think I would change a thing.

Me and my friend were in Montreal for a one day trip. We were walking on the street of Old port and saw this place that has cheese fondue! I have been wanting to try cheese fondue for a long time so we decided to have something small here. The atmosphere is cozy and quiet. The waitress is super friendly! We ordered French Onion soup and a Swiss fondue with white wine and kirsh. The soup is nice and has a sweet and rich flavour (what can go wrong with a French onion soup?) Personally, I like the fondue! My friend think the wine flavour is a bit strong and bitter, so maybe a little bit less wine flavour would be nicer? The waitress even asked us if we wants more bread! If we ever come back to Montreal, we would probably come back to try some other thing on the menu!

This place was amazing. We searched all over old Montreal for a fondue place and this definitely hit the spot. Our server, Stephany was the sweetest person ever. We had the bruschetta and French onion soup to start as well as the trio of fondue. The cheese was incredible, and the beef broth for the second course was so succulent. We would definitely return!
Great french onion soup, tasty lobster bisque soup, and the "Sonia crepe", sublime! Great fast service.
I really wouldn't have thought Brie, apples, and syrup would go so well in a crepe! The three-cheese crepe was also great. I'd love to have tried the dessert crepes.
The waitress's recommendation, Butter sugar crepe with strawberry, was really good, but I am pretty sure I can find the better one in somewhere. not that special, but it was good.

The quiche Lorraine was delicious - but it's the service that gets 5 stars! My dad forget his bag at the table and the waitress tracked us down almost three blocks away to give it back!! And it was cold out! MERCI BEAUCOUP MADEMOISELLE!!!!!! :)

Honestly--just go here, MANY times, and eat MANY crepes. Decor is cute, we sat on the second floor in front of an open window that faced Rue St Paul which was gorgeous. Service, as with most places in Montreal, in English, French or my particular brand of English-French hybrid. 

My husband ordered an egg, bacon and cheese filled breakfast crepe with pure maple syrup, and I opted for ham, brie, and spinach with bechamel sauce. Large portions, even though I was starving and tried my hardest to finish I could not! Also amazing milkshakes, and iced cappuccino.

A must visit if you're in Old Montreal.

Great fondue and soups. Poor service. Waitstaff non responsive to requests unless you asked multiple times. Took 15 minutes from getting check to processing payment. Waited 10 minutes for waiter to come back to take order after he said he would right back.   In the meantime he cleared off two other tables

I am very picky about crepes. This place was pretty great. Pretty awesome location on St. Paul in Old Montreal, you can't miss it. We ran in there because it was -28'C (aaaaaahhhhhh!!!!!!!) out and I didn't feel like poutine. We got there and the atmosphere was cozy and everything smelled good and the people were so nice and it was so warm. We sighed as we sat down by the window. Savory crepes are good, dessert crepes are better. Soups au gratin are really really good. Hot chocolate is excellent. Ham sandwich is eh. View outside is kinda romantic, which isn't difficult on that street. Price isn't really cheap, but worth it. Eat there.

I come back to this establishment every time I am in Montreal for both savory and sweet crepes. Staff is very friendly. My only negative comment would be for them to repaint/re-design the place so it is more inviting and pleasing. Right now it is bare bones and a bit used and abused.

Yeah Chez Suzette is a good crepe place. I got the Canadian Crepe which was nice. I location is very nice in the heart of Vieux-Montreal. The waitress we got was nice, and spoke pretty good english. The milkshakes here are also very good.
Hh

Let's just say I was craving crêpes. 

I selected the Délicieuse, $14, which was loaded with bananas, topped with sliced almonds and a toffee cream sauce, with ice cream on the side. Good balance of flavours and crêpe-to-accompaniments ratio. The crêpe itself was the perfect thickness.

The Café Viennois (Viennese coffee) was satisfactory while the Chocolat Chaud was rich and above average. Both were $5.

The décor is outdated and I can understand the lukewarm reviews. Although I wouldn't specifically come here, this quaint little café is a nice option to pop into when walking around Old Montréal.

We ate here our  first night in Montréal.  We picked it at random and were not disappointed. The food was delish. We did cheese fondue, which was awesome!  They had lots of great dinner and dessert crepe choices. We came back for brunch and had excellent dessert crepes, and the French onion soup is a must! The staff was attentive and friendly, and the ambiance had a cute corner café feel. A gem in a bit of a touristy area.

Nice fun place to dine and people-watch, but don't expect cuisine. We got a table inside overlooking the procession on St. Paul St, a great view. But the cheese fondue - one of their specialties - was a huge disappointment. Instead of baguette chunks, we got cranberry bread, olive bread - soft, gummy breads. And the cheese lacked the punch you get from kirsch; our packaged fondue from Trader Joes tastes better. 
The Caesar salad - admittedly a side order - was devoid of Caesar flavor; just chopped lettuce and croutons. Likewise, their Suzette Sundae, a concoction of Grand Marnier,  cognac, and ice cream, was mostly melted ice cream, more to be slurped thru a straw than eaten with a spoon. Food was definitely phoned in. 
The resto is attractive, outside and in; service was fast and friendly and responsive. I just wish the food had been as likable. 3 stars max.

I heard about the famous onion soup from Suzette and I was also drawn by this French bistro because I visited France two years ago. I was disappointed by the quality and service since the food was quite plain and overpriced, same for the sangria that we ordered. We sat on the terrace and had a good time talking, but the food (salmon salad and onion soup) and the drink were below average. Yet, since the restaurant is located at the intersection of St-Laurent and St-Paul, many tourists are willing to pay ridiculous amount to eat at this place, but honestly there are much better options for the same price around the same area.

Delicious savory and dessert crepes. A great spot in Old Montreal to sit and look out over the old stone road while eating this French delight. I stop here every time I am in town. Probably my favorite crepe joint in North America. The services is great too; friendly and fast.
We wanted to stay with the Parisian theme, so stopped by this cute little place. We had different crepes and chocolate fondue to finish it up. Friendly service and quick turn around.

I ordered the crepes for dessert and they were cold and thick in texture. The ice cream served with it was gummy, horrible texture. The toffee cream and sliced almonds were good. The group I was with ordered the crepes Suzette and it tasted like orange cough syrup and again the crepes were cold.
Bland tourist food. Food came barely warm. Bland dry chicken in chicken/ratatouille crepe with bland barely-melted mozzarella. Lobster bisque ok but little hint of lobster or sherry.

Great location in Old Montreal and the old-world feel of the restaurant add to its charm. Service was not great, but aside from that the food was pretty good. There are some nice salad option which can be tough to find so if you're looking for some good greens this is a good location for you. Lots of sweet and savory crepes and fondue options.

I LOVED my Parisienne crepe which had apples, brie and of course some maple syrup. Many of the other crepes included cheese and some more cheese on top...I felt like my dinner option was sutto healthy.  Chocolate fondue is a must and one portion was very generous. Our dessert was accompanied by loads of fresh fruit, bits of crepe and marshmallow.

We went for Fondue, but ended up tasting it and giving it back. We than ordered a crepe with nutella and bananas and got a Crepe with Nutella and strawberries instead.... I also ordered a cup of hot tea but never got it... waitress wasn't great... the reason for 3 Stars is; she didn't charge us for the Fondue...
If you go, try the crepes, the fondue isn't great at all...
Will I be back? Possibly...

We came here for a birthday dinner and the service, food, and atmosphere we received was fantastic. Our waiter was very friendly and helpful, and seated us on the second floor where we got a lovely view of the bustling streets of Old Montreal. I ordered La Méditerranéenne Crêpe, a baked crêpe filled with chicken and ratatouille, topped with generous amounts of mozzarella cheese. I also had the Bellini Fraise drink, which tasted a little strong in my opinion (but I'm quite a lightweight). For dessert, two friends and I shared the Fondue au Chocolat pour 2, and the dark chocolate was very smooth and rich. If you tell the waiter that it's someone's birthday, they will bring the dessert out  with a candle in it while singing happy birthday. Overall, I was very satisfied with my meal and will definitely go back there when I get the chance.

It is not easy to find a place for a Fondue on a Sunday, during lunch time. I've found this place on Yelp and decided to give shot.

The place is huge. Two or three floors I think! The service is friendly. I've found the full fondue meal (cheese & meet & chocolate) off MY budget, but not too bad. 

The cheese fondue was delicious. I loved the veggies that came with it. The meet one was ok. Nothing special. The chocolate... Well... It's chocolate. Of course it was amazing! 

One thing that bothered me was that the timing wasn't good. It took too long between the services and we spent almost the entire afternoon there. 

Overall, it was nice for the company we've had, but I'm not sure I'll be back.

Ate here first day in Montreal. Food was very fresh, service was good. Ordered a chef salad and bruschetta.  Both delicious.  The dressing on the salad was super tasty; mustard vinaigrette.  I would definitely eat here again.  This place is usually a busy..definitely a good sign.

Great place to grab a crepe in Old Montreal. The hot chocolate was amazing and I really enjoyed my crepe. Nothing like a strawberry, banana and chocolate crepe for breakfast (La Sonia Crepe). I think the best thing about the restaurant is the ability to sit outside at a bistro table and people watch.

We stayed right on Rue St Paul in the heart of Old Montreal and found this a very convenient spot to have a relaxing lunch on a cold snowy afternoon.

We decided to have one of the special combos for two for $59.95.

We each started with a caesar salad.

Next we had each had a choice of either french onion soup or escargots.  My wife chose the former and I chose the latter.  Both were well executed and perfect on such a cold afternoon.

Next came the cheese fondue.  It tasted like the fondue that my mother would have made for us back in the 1970s.  They served it with 3 types, or so, of bread and some cut up apples.

Lastly, we got to choose between crepe suzette or crepe viennoise.  My wife chose the former and I chose the latter.  I am not big fan of Grand Marnier so I didn't even taste hers.  However, she said it was excellent.  I enjoyed the chocolately goodness of mine.

It was a good stop and enjoyable meal!

Amazing place! The best crepe I've ever had! And also the best sangria as well! Price is fair, service is very good!  Remember to make a reservation in advance! The place is in Old Montreal, which is very cute and pleasant to visit!

I had the most horrible experience in that restaurant... we arrived to the restaurant before 7... we didnt get our entree until 9... we had to ask and remind that we hadn't ate... all we ordered were cheese fondues... we saw people who came after us left already... and the quality of the fondue wasn't even good... i had better in NYC... 

the service was terrible as well... we asked the waitress to lite the candles for the fondue(she only lite 1 candle which the cheese wasn't even hot) she told us all the excuses that she couldn't lite them while there are like 5 candles underneath...

At the end, i requested for the manager... her reason for havin us waited for the fondue was the restaurant was really busy... dun feel sorry at all...

I'm not a picky eater and I normally don't write bad reviews but this place is a one star.  Terrible service, foods was really bad, the eggs weren't cooked properly and the crepe was very rubbery and dry. Do not recommend it

Cute little diner in the heart of old Montreal. We made reservations and sat outside. It was a nice area of town and good people watching. We ordered cheese fondue- delicious - with bread fruits and veggies. We also ordered and ham and cheese crepe with bechamel sauce- YUM, and we ordered escargot covered sigh cheese and garlic. Legit!  It was like a trip to France! And we ordered a bottle of Chardonnay! Super delicious, intimate meal on one of the oldest streets in Montreal! Would highly suggest making reservations and sitting outside. We were happy with all of our food selections !

I visited Montreal with my parents and took them to Chez Suzette. We got the 3 fondue combo that was a perfect meal that was very filling and totally worth the price. Whether you're looking for a quick bite to eat or there to enjoy a 3 hour long 3 course meal, Chez Suzette is a quaint place in Old Montreal that's worth a stop.

They had a very good menu with lots of choices. That whole vegetarian section which is just fine by me. They had a good selection of wines as well as apple cider. The place is big inside as well as you can sit outside. The crapes were delicious and the portions plenty. My friends also had crepes as well as a salad and soups and they were very satisfied and finished all their portions. The service was attentive and friendly. I would recommend this place and definitely return.

I'm about to drop some fondue knowledge on you AND give Chez Suzette their centennial review? Now that's what I'm talkin' about...

I was all about revisiting this place during my last visit to Old Town, Montreal. I have this on going joke going with my significant other that goes like this "Have you been there before on a date?"* The answer is sadly often yes, because we met in our late 20s/early 30s and are both people that eat out way too often. In whatever city we're in. Anyway, when it was time to play this round I finally got to say "only with my mom and my best friend's little sister." This was bittersweet, as I felt like I won, but then he didn't try to outdo any other scenario. Wow. Talk about TMI. Moving on.

I know this is a creperie, but I disagree. Suzette's finest is her fondue. I've had the original emmental and this time the three cheese and pepper. Delicious. I know others say the prices are jacked up because of this touristy location, but I got a bottle of French merlot (No one is drinking merlot!!! -Sad Paul Giamatti) for under $20 and shared the gooey gooey goodness with my SO. The small is definitely enough to share, and they offer to bring you free bread when you run low. Creperie Chez Suzette is a two-storey building with a patio located in the central tourist area in Old Montreal. It serves a large selection of crepes and fondue. 

At my visit, I had the French crepe with stuffed ham, Brie and caramelized onions served with 100% pure Quebec maple syrup. It was delicious! It was hands down the best crepe I have ever had.

I would highly recommend this place to all! If you're looking for a local authentic meal, this is it!
